citation.article-title: Methylobacterium suomiense sp. nov. and Methylobacterium lusitanum sp. nov., aerobic, pink-pigmented, facultatively methylotrophic bacteria.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Methylobacterium lusitanum sp. nov.
Methylobacterium lusitanum (lu.si.ta'num. L. neut. adj. lusitanum of Lusitania, the Latin name of Portugal)
Gram-negative, asporogenous rods, 1.0-1.2x1.7-2.0 μm, occurring singly or rarely in pairs.
Cells are motile by a single or two to three polar flagella.
Slow growth on nutrient agar and PYG agar.
Colonies on methanol/salt agar are shiny, smooth, raised, entire and pink, 1 mm in diameter after 3 days growth at 30 °C.
The pink pigment is water insoluble and has absorption maxima at 473, 499 and 532 nm in a mixture of chloroform and methanol (1:1).
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite.
Methyl red and Voges-Proskauer tests are negative.
Produces indole from tryptophan on medium with nitrate as nitrogen source.
Does not hydrolyse gelatin or starch.
Does not form ammonia or hydrogen sulfide.
Produces acid oxidatively from D-fructose.
Catalase-, oxidase-, lipase- and urease-positive.
Oxidase activity is weak.
Strict aerobe.
Chemo-organotroph and facultative methylotroph, assimilating C1 compounds by the icl− serine pathway.
Utilized carbon sources are:methanol, methylamine, ethanol, glycerol, inositol, D-fructose, acetate, acetamide, succinate, malate, fumarate, pyruvate, α-ketoglutarate and propionate.

The following are not utilized: L-arabinose, D-glucose, galactose, D-xylose, mannose, lactose, maltose, trehalose, raffinose, rhamnose, ribose, sucrose, sorbose, sorbitol, mannitol, inositol, soluble starch, tartrate, citrate, alanine, valine, glycine, arginine, aspartate, betaine, N,N-dimethylglycine, sarcosine, glutamate, mono- and dichloromethane, di- and trimethylamine, CO2­H2 and methane.
Growth factors are not required.
Ammonium salts, nitrate, urea, aspartate, glutamate and alanine are utilized as nitrogen sources.
Optimal growth between pH 6.9 and 7.5 and at 30-37 °C.
No growth occurs in the presence of 3% NaCl.
The main cellular fatty acid is cisvaccenic acid (C"):"x7; 83.1%).
The major ubiquinone is Q-10.
Dominant phospholipids are phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylcholine.
The G­C content of the DNA is 66.5 mol%(Tm).

The type strain, RXMT, was isolated from a sewage station in Portugal as a methanol-utilizing bacterium and has been deposited in the Russian Collection of Microorganisms as VKM B-2239T, in the National Collections of Industrial, Food and Marine Bacteria as NCIMB 13779T and in the DSMZ as DSM 14457T.
